title: Arthur Justice
text:
Arthur "Snowy" Justice (1902–1977) was an Australian <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer, coach and administrator. He was a rugged for the <a href="St%20George%20Dragons">St George Dragons</a> who made <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20state%20rugby%20league%20team">state</a> and <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">national representative</a> appearances in the late 1920s. Later he was a club administrator, national selector and league judiciary Chairman.
Club career.
A pioneer player with the St George Dragons, he made his first grade debut in the club's second season in the <a href="NSWRFL">NSWRFL</a>. He captained the club in their maiden (and unsuccessful) <a href="Grand%20final">Grand final</a> appearance in <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season%201930%23Final">season 1930</a> against the <a href="Western%20Suburbs%20Magpies">Western Suburbs Magpies</a>. This was the first ever Grand Final played to determine the premiership winner. In <a href="1932%20NSWRFL%20season">season 1932</a> when his <a href="Kangaroo%20tour">Kangaroo tour</a>ist partner <a href="Harry%20Kadwell">Harry Kadwell</a> was captain-coach at St George, Justice took over the captaincy when Kadwell's season was ended with a broken leg.
Representative career.
An uncompromising player and relentless fighter <ref name="Whiticker/Hudson p 276">Whiticker/Hudson p 276</ref> Justice first represented for <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20League%20team">New South Wales</a> in 1925 and went on to make a total of 25 appearances for his state.
Justice made his Test debut for <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Australia</a> in the first match of <a href="The%20Ashes">Ashes</a> series against <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">England</a> in 1928 and played in all three Tests of that series. He made further Test appearances on the <a href="1929%E2%80%9330%20Kangaroo%20tour%20of%20Great%20Britain">1929–30 Kangaroo tour of Great Britain</a> - the scoreless draw in the third test and the subsequent fourth test, as well as appearing in a tour match against Wales. Arthur Justice is listed on the "Australian Players Register" as Kangaroo No. 139.
Post playing, administrative career and accolades.
Justice coached the <a href="St.%20George%20Dragons">St. George Dragons</a> in two seasons <a href="1936%20NSWRFL%20season">1936</a> and <a href="1947%20NSWRFL%20season">1947</a>. He was an Australian representative selector for the 1952-53 Kangaroos and was chairman of the <a href="NSWRFL">NSWRFL</a> judiciary. He was also instrumental in enticing <a href="Frank%20Facer">Frank Facer</a> to St.George in 1947.
He then enjoyed a long career as Secretary-Manager of the St George Leagues Club initially at the club's first premises at the head of Rocky Point Road, <a href="Kogarah%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Kogarah</a> and then from 1963 when the current Leagues Club was opened on the Princes Highway at <a href="Carlton%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Carlton</a> up until his death.
He was awarded Life Membership of the <a href="St.%20George%20Dragons">St. George Dragons</a> club in 1944.
Together with the Balmain administrator <a href="Norm%20Robinson">Latchem Robinson</a>, Justice's former representative playing peer, he was one of the seminal forces behind the establishment of the <a href="Club%20Managers%27%20Association%20Australia">Club Managers' Association</a> of Australia at its foundation in 1964. Justice was awarded a Life Membership of that organisation for outstanding service to the club industry.
Death.
Arthur Justice died on 16 December 1977 aged 75.
